clusters.title: Officer killed in Porepunkah shooting farewelled
clusters.neutral_headline: Funeral Held for Officer Killed in Porepunkah Shooting
bullet_summary: Reported by 9News, The Age, ABC News Australia

items.title: Officer killed in Porepunkah shooting farewelled
items.standfirst: Vadim de Waart-Hottart was killed alongside his colleague at a Porepunkah property whilst they were serving a warrant.
items.content: More than 1000 people have gathered together this morning to pay their respects to Senior Constable Vadim de Waart-Hottart.The 34-year-old Belgian national was one of two police officers shot in cold blood at a Porepunkah property on August 26 whilst they were serving a warrant.Prime Minister Anthony Albanese and Victorian Premier Jacinta Allan are among those attending the funeral at the Victoria Police Academy in Glen Waverley.READ MORE: More officers deployed to search for accused gunman ahead of slain cop's funeralSpeaking during the service was the senior constable's heartbroken brother, Sasha de Waart-Hottart."My brother, the hero. I could spend hours speaking about my brother, about the wonderful person he is, about all the amazing times we had together. But I'm going to keep this short because I'm not sure I would be able to get through it without breaking down," he said.Senior Constable de Waart-Hottart, was killed alongside his colleague Detective Leading Senior Constable Neal Thompson, 59.The hunt for accused double murderer Dezi Freeman is continuing in Victoria's high country, with 450 police officers dedicated to the search.Detective Neal Thompson's funeral will be held on Monday. De Waart-Hottart had been on secondment to Wangaratta from Melbourne and served Victoria Police for seven years.In a poignant Facebook post earlier this morning, Victoria Police shared a photograph of de Waart-Hottart with an artwork which had been sent to him as a gift of appreciation from a community member some years ago.De Waart-Hottart had attended a mental health incident with a colleague and provided support to that community member when they were in crisis, Victoria Police said."As a thank you, that person painted portraits of both officers," the post read."It's a small but powerful reminder of the quiet, positive impact our members have in the community every day â€“ often without recognition or expectation. It's through gestures like these that we remember Vadim as someone who devoted his career to helping others."Police Association Victoria secretary Wayne Gatt released a statement honouring de Waart-Hottart ahead of the funeral."Six years in a job you love is too short. A life that gave more than it took, to have been ended in such a way, is an indescribable injustice and a tragedy," Gatt said."Senior Constable Vadim de Waart-Hottart, you wore the uniform with honour and you represented it with kindness, compassion and a just heart."To your loving family both here and abroad, we want you to know that your loss is shared by the policing family, colleagues and friends of Vadim and an eternally grateful Victorian community."Today we farewell Senior Constable Vadim de Waart-Hottart, but we will never forget him."Sign up here to receive our daily newsletters and breaking news alerts, sent straight to your inbox.

clusters.title: Australians left with 'ugly' teeth and no super are unlikely to see their money again
clusters.neutral_headline: Australians Face Financial Loss from Dental Clinic Closure

items.title: Australians left with 'ugly' teeth and no super are unlikely to see their money again
items.standfirst: A creditorâ€™s report into Supercare Dental and Cosmetics Tuggerah reveals almost $3 million in unsecured creditor claims with little chance patients will be able to recoup their money.

ai_summary: Patients of Supercare Dental and Cosmetics Tuggerah face losses.
A creditor's report reveals almost $3 million in claims.
Unsecured creditors are unlikely to recover their money.
Patients may have "ugly" teeth and no superannuation.
The clinic has closed, leaving patients with debt.

clusters.title: Coalition of 26 countries commit to Ukraine post-war peacekeeping force
clusters.neutral_headline: Twenty-Six Countries Commit to Ukraine Peacekeeping Force

items.title: Coalition of 26 countries commit to Ukraine post-war peacekeeping force
items.standfirst: The forces would be deployed on day one of any peace deal between Ukraine and Russia, aiming to prevent another invasion of the country.
items.content: The forces would be deployed on day one of any peace deal between Ukraine and Russia, aiming to prevent another invasion of the country.

ai_summary: A coalition of twenty-six countries is forming a peacekeeping force.
The force would deploy after a peace deal.
The aim is to prevent another invasion of Ukraine.
The force would be deployed on day one.
The initiative supports Ukraine's security.

clusters.title: PM says he had 'warm and constructive' conversation with Trump
clusters.neutral_headline: Prime Minister Discusses Trade with Donald Trump

items.title: PM says he had 'warm and constructive' conversation with Trump
items.standfirst: The prime minister says the pair had a "warm and constructive" conversation about trade, critical minerals and shared security interests.
items.content: The prime minister says the pair had a "warm and constructive" conversation about trade, critical minerals and shared security interests.

ai_summary: The Prime Minister had a conversation with Donald Trump.
The conversation was described as "warm and constructive".
They discussed trade matters.
Critical minerals were also a topic of discussion.
Shared security interests were also discussed.
